title: 107_hr3223
content: The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct these systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act aims to provide safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It includes service connections to facilities in Dulce and the surrounding area, and individuals as part of the construction. The Secretary is required to enter into a self-determination contract with the Jicarilla Apache Nation for planning and design. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems, including service connections. The Bureau of Reclamation will provide technical assistance and oversight. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. The section defines key terms. Key terms defined in the Act include "Act" referring to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, "BIA" as the Bureau of Indian Affairs, "irrigation" as the commercial application of water for agriculture, and "Reclamation" as the Bureau of Reclamation. The term "Report" refers to a report titled "Planning Report/Environmental Assessment, Water and Wastewater Improvements, Jicarilla Apache Nation, Dulce, New Mexico" completed under Public Law 106-243. The term "Reservation" pertains to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, including lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. The term "Rural water supply project" is defined as a project for providing water supply in rural areas. The term "Rural Water Supply Project" refers to a facility serving towns, communities, cities, tribal reservations, or farmsteads with clean water, including livestock use. The term "State" specifically means New Mexico, while "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" pertains to the Jicarilla Apache Nation. SEC. 4. JICARILLA APACHE RESERVATION RURAL WATER SYSTEM. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation. The Rural Water Supply Project will include pumping and treatment facilities, distribution, collection, and treatment facilities for water and wastewater services in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding areas on the Reservation. This will involve construction, replacement, improvement, and repair of existing systems, as well as necessary property rights and access roads. The Rural Water Supply Project will include various facilities such as pipelines, pumping plants, and water storage tanks to meet the Reservation's water supply needs. The tribal share of the project costs includes design and initiation expenses. The Rural Water Supply Project includes costs for designing and starting construction of various facilities like a wastewater treatment plant, diversion structure replacement, raw water settling ponds, water treatment plant, storage plants, transmission pipeline, and distribution pipelines. The Federal share covers all remaining project costs identified in the Report. Upon completion of the Rural Water Supply Project, the Tribe will be responsible for the operation, maintenance, and replacement costs as per the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Tribe will be responsible for the cost of the project as per the Indian Self-Determination Act and the Operation, Maintenance, and Replacement Plan. The Secretary has the authority to enter agreements and regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary shall prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project within 60 days of funds availability, including maps and engineering drawings. The Tribe must develop an OM&R plan for operation, maintenance, and replacement, to establish rates for project customers. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will select a construction manager for the Rural Water Supply Project. A memorandum of agreement will be entered into with the Tribe to address operations and maintenance during and after construction. The Secretary will have oversight responsibility. The Secretary will provide oversight and technical assistance to the Tribe for the Rural Water Supply Project within the Reservation boundaries, subject to applicable laws. The Rural Water Supply Project under the Indian Self-Determination Act will be overseen by the Secretary and held in trust for the Tribe by the United States. Annual reports on the project's progress will be submitted to Congress. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of $45,000,000 for the Rural Water Supply Project planning, design, and construction, subject to completion of appraisal investigation and feasibility study by the Secretary and the Tribe. The Secretary and the Tribe must complete the required plan for the Rural Water Supply Project before funds can be allocated for construction, in compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. SEC. 8 prohibits the use of funds for irrigation purposes in the Rural Water Supply Project. SEC. 9 addresses water rights. The Jicarilla Apache Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act (Public Law 102-441) adjudicates the Tribe's water rights under New Mexico State law. These rights provide sufficient water for the municipal water system, recognized depletions in the San Juan River basin, with no new depletions from the Rural Water Supply Project. Reclamation, in consultation with the Fish and Wildlife Service, has confirmed this. The Rural Water Supply Project will not impact endangered species or the Tribe's water rights.
